perturbation.original_text: "Prudent Electrical Practices" means those practices, methods, equipment, specifications and standards of safety and performance, as the same may change from time to time, as are commonly used by a significant portion of the grid-tied electrical generation industry operating in the United States as good, safe and prudent engineering practices in connection with the design, construction, operation, maintenance, repair and use of electrical and other equipment, facilities and improvements of such electrical generating facility, including any applicable practices, methods, acts, guidelines, standards and criteria of FERC, PJM, and all applicable Legal Requirements.
perturbation.changed_text: "Prudent Electrical Practices" means those suggestions, methods, equipment, specifications, and standards of safety and performance, as the same may change from time to time, that are preferred by the Operator.
perturbation.explanation: The original definition adheres to industry standards and legal requirements, while the modified definition makes 'Prudent Electrical Practices' subjective and controlled solely by the Operator. This introduces ambiguity and conflicts with standard grid operation protocols, potentially violating regulations by allowing the operator's preference to override established safety and performance standards. The original definition is based on standards in United States while the changed is only based on operator preferences.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) guidelines and North American Electric Reliability Corporation (NERC) standards.

perturbation.original_text: "Force Majeure Event" means any event or circumstance that (a) prevents a Party from performing its obligations under this Agreement; (b) was not foreseeable by such Party; (c) was not within the reasonable control of, or the result of the negligence of such Party; and (d) such Party is unable to reasonably mitigate, avoid or cause to be avoided with the exercise of due diligence. It shall include failure or interruption of performance due to: an act of God, civil or military authority, war, civil disturbances, terrorist activities, fire, explosions, the elements, the gas supplier's failure to comply with gas delivery, quality or pressure requirements, the external power delivery system (a/k/a the grid) being out of the required specifications or total failure (a/k/a brownout or blackout), PJM or other electric grid curtailment, or failure of equipment not utilized by or under the control of the Party claiming the Force Majeure Event (or any Affiliate or subcontractor of such Party). Force Majeure Event does not include the lack of economic resources of a Party or Operator's failure to design and construct the Bloom Systems and the BOF so as to meet the respective warranties hereunder.
perturbation.changed_text: "Force Majeure Event" means any event or circumstance that prevents a Party from performing its obligations under this Agreement. It shall include failure or interruption of performance due to: lack of available personnel, economic downturns, or any other factor deemed relevant by the claiming party.
perturbation.explanation: The original definition includes specific, unforeseen events beyond a party's control, consistent with legal interpretations of force majeure. The modified definition broadens the scope to include foreseeable events like 'lack of available personnel' or 'economic downturns,' which are typically not considered force majeure under contract law. This attempts to excuse performance based on factors within a party's control, conflicting with established legal precedents.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Common law principles of contract interpretation regarding Force Majeure and UCC ยง 2-615 (Excuse by Failure of Presupposed Conditions).

perturbation.original_text: Operator shall operate and maintain the Portfolio, or cause the Portfolio to be operated and maintained, within amounts for (a) any Operating Budget Category (as defined in the Credit Documents) that is applicable to the Facility Services not to exceed 110% (on a year-to-date basis) and (b) for all Operating Budget Categories (or such Operating Budget Categories applicable to the Facility Services) not to exceed 105% (on a year- to-date basis), in each case of the amounts budgeted therefor as set forth in the then-current Annual Operating Budget (as defined in the Credit Documents).
perturbation.changed_text: Operator shall operate and maintain the Portfolio at their discretion, with no budgetary constraints.
perturbation.explanation: The original text contains clear constraints for the budget in which the operator should work with. The modified test allows the Operator to operate without budgetary concerns, which contradicts the intention of the contract, and opens the door for economic mismanagements.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Breach of Fiduciary Duty, Corporate Negligence.
